FacilityName: Altamont Landfill and Resource Recovery Facility
ParentCompanyName: Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Programs (RMP) have been prepared for Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc.'s (WMAC) Altamont Landfill and Resource Recovery Facility located in Alameda County, California.  The facility has two regulated processes onsite that both use liquefied natural gas (LNG): Altamont LNG facility and LCNG Fueling Station. The RMP's developed for each of these processes address United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) RMP requirements. Finally, because this facility is subject to the Occupational Health and Safety (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards, the RMP's are designed to meet the specific requirements of those standards as well.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



It is Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc.'s policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc. is committed to protect the health and safety of its employees and the public. In order to achieve this objective, Waste Management has allocated and invested considerable resources in implementing reasonable controls to prevent predictable releases of LNG and LCNG by training its employees, by the safe design, installation, maintenance and operation of this facility, and by installing fire and leak detection and mitigation systems.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Waste Management Of Alameda County, Inc.'s Altamont Landfill and Resource Recovery Facility is located at 10840 Altamont Pass Road in unincorporated Alameda County near Livermore, California.  The facility is approximately 2.1 miles north of Interstate 580 and 16 miles east of Interstate 680. The area immediately surrounding the facility is mostly undeveloped with the closest industrial buildings located approximately 2 miles away.



The facility has two regulated processes onsite that both use LNG: the Altamont LNG facility (Highland Mountain Fuels, LLC.) and the LCNG Fueling Station. Methane, whi

ch is the major component of LNG, is considered hazardous by the USEPA. LNG is a flammable gas. It is stored at -258.7 degrees C. It is a clean burning fuel.



Altamont LNG Facility:

The Altamont LNG facility is owned by Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc. and operated by Linde, LLC via High Mountain Fuels, LLC. The primary purpose of this facility is to convert landfill gas to LNG. The LNG will be dispensed at the facility into trucks for transport to an off-site facility where it will be used for fueling vehicles. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel, and contractors. The maximum intended inventory of LNG for this process is 180,000 lbs. 



LCNG Fueling Station:

The LCNG Fueling Station is owned and operated by WM.  The process employed in the fueling station involves converting liquefied natural gas (LNG) to compressed natural gas (CNG), which in turn will be used as a fuel to power solid waste transfer trucks operated by Waste Management. Typical operating conditions range from 60-110 psig on the low pressure LNG system to 4,200 psig on the CNG side.  Construction of the fueling system began in 2011, with operations beginning in March 2012.  The system's maximum intended inventory of 50,750 pounds.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc. to prevent the accidental release of LNG or LCNG at the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the systems are operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the systems are in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modificatio

ns are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before LNG is introduced into a new or modified process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of LNG and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



In addition, to ensure worker and community safety, the facility includes numerous mechanisms for preventing accidents. These include designing the facility to meet all current design standards (including National Fire Protection Association [NFPA]-59A [Standard for the Production, Storage, and Handling of Liquefied Natural Gas] for the Altamont LNG Facility, NFPA-52 [Vehicular Gaseous Fuel Systems Code] for the LCNG Fueling Station, and those applicable to earthquake safety); regular facility maintenance; worker training regarding facility operation, safe LNG handling procedures, and response to accidents; leak and fire detection systems; emergency shutdown procedures; and compliance audits. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no reportable releases of LNG from the Altamont LNG facility since it began operations in 2009.  The five-year accident history is not applicable to the LCNG Fueling Station as it is a new process. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Waste Management of Alameda County, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

 

?    save lives;

?    minimize and avoid injuries;

?    protect the environment; and

?    minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, LNG health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.



Emergency response at this f

acility will be handled by the Alameda County Fire Department.  Facility personnel will not be expected to perform emergency response activities apart from: 1) reporting an incident (LNG leak or fire) when it occurs, 2) activating any facility-wide notification system, and 3) evacuating the facility to a safe location. 

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis, performed in July, 2014 for the Altamont LNG Facility and on May 25, 2017 for the LCNG Fueling Station, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Waste Management facility.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  Waste Management is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility's safety plans/programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in the development of the facility's safety plans/programs.



3. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
